etymology.description: 沒(沒) (méi, "no; not") + 錯(錯) (cuò, "wrong; mistake") suggests a negation of error, effectively conveying the idea of correctness or affirmation.
etymology.interpretation: The phrase 没错(沒錯) (méi cuò, "that's right; correct") is used to affirm or confirm a statement, indicating that there is no error or mistake in what was said. It combines the negation '没(沒)' (méi, "no; not") with '错(錯)' (cuò, "wrong; mistake") to produce a positive affirmation.

examples.chinese: 他说的没错(他說的沒錯)。
他解释得很清楚(他解釋得很清楚)，没错(沒錯)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jiěshì dé hěn qīngchǔ, méi cuò.
examples.english: His explanation is very clear, that's right.

examples.chinese: 你理解了小说的情节(你理解了小說的情節)，没错(沒錯)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ lǐjiě le xiǎoshuō de qíngjié, méi cuò.
examples.english: You understood the plot of the novel, exactly.
